<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 875, 648]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.- Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 216, 696]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 696, 732, 728]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 81, 675, 317]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 333, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
Coplanar forces of magnitudes \(60\mathrm{N}, 20\mathrm{N}, 16\mathrm{N}\) and \(14\mathrm{N}\) act at a point in the directions shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 380, 560, 400]]<|/det|>
Find the magnitude and direction of the resultant force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 381, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
Two particles \(A\) and \(B\), of masses \(2.4 \mathrm{kg}\) and \(1.2 \mathrm{kg}\) respectively, are connected by a light inextensible string which passes over a fixed smooth pulley. \(A\) is held at a distance of \(2.1 \mathrm{m}\) above a horizontal plane and \(B\) is \(1.5 \mathrm{m}\) above the plane. The particles hang vertically and are released from rest. In the subsequent motion \(A\) reaches the plane and does not rebound and \(B\) does not reach the pulley.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 152, 146, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 151, 920, 185]]<|/det|>
Show that the tension in the string before \(A\) reaches the plane is \(16 \mathrm{N}\) and find the magnitude of the acceleration of the particles before \(A\) reaches the plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 166, 920, 185]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 141]]<|/det|>
A particle \(A\), moving along a straight horizontal track with constant speed \(8 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\), passes a fixed point \(O\). Four seconds later, another particle \(B\) passes \(O\), moving along a parallel track in the same direction as \(A\). Particle \(B\) has speed \(20 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) when it passes \(O\) and has a constant deceleration of \(2 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 2}\). \(B\) comes to rest when it returns to \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 153, 146, 171]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 152, 920, 186]]<|/det|>
Find expressions, in terms of \(t\), for the displacement from \(O\) of each particle \(t\) seconds after \(B\) passes \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 168, 920, 186]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[374, 82, 660, 243]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 260, 920, 327]]<|/det|>
A block of mass \(12\mathrm{kg}\) is placed on a plane which is inclined at an angle of \(24^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. A light string, making an angle of \(36^{\circ}\) above a line of greatest slope, is attached to the block. The tension in the string is \(65\mathrm{N}\) (see diagram). The coefficient of friction between the block and plane is \(\mu\). The block is in limiting equilibrium and is on the point of sliding up the plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 339, 180, 357]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 339, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
A car of mass \(900\mathrm{kg}\) is moving up a hill inclined at \(\sin^{- 1}0.12\) to the horizontal. The initial speed of the car is \(11\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\). After \(12\mathrm{s}\), the car has travelled \(150\mathrm{m}\) up the hill and has speed \(16\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\). The engine of the car is working at a constant rate of \(24\mathrm{kW}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 146, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 136, 655, 155]]<|/det|>
Find the work done against the resistive forces during the 12 s.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 136, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
The car then travels along a straight horizontal road. There is a resistance to the motion of the car of \((1520 + 4v)\mathrm{N}\) when the speed of the car is \(v\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) . The car travels at a constant speed with the engine working at a constant rate of \(32\mathrm{kW}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 136, 148, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 136, 287, 153]]<|/det|>
Find this speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 136, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 650, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the total distance covered by \(P\) in the interval \(0 \leqslant t \leqslant 20\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]
